intro_what_is_cypress.title: What is Cypress?
intro_what_is_cypress.description: Learn about Cypress and why it's a powerful testing framework
intro_what_is_cypress.content: Cypress is a next-generation front-end testing tool built for the modern web. It addresses the key pain points developers and QA engineers face when testing modern applications.

concepts.title: Key Concepts
items: **Fast, Easy and Reliable**: Cypress runs much faster than traditional testing tools because it operates directly in the browser
**Time Travel**: Cypress takes snapshots as tests run, allowing you to hover over commands to see exactly what happened
**Real-time Reloads**: Automatically reloads whenever you make changes to your tests
**Debuggable**: Readable errors and stack traces make debugging lightning fast

intro_installation.title: Installation & Setup
intro_installation.description: Install Cypress and configure your first project
intro_installation.content: Setting up Cypress is straightforward. Let's walk through the installation process step by step.
steps: Install Cypress via npm: `npm install --save-dev cypress`
Open Cypress for the first time: `npx cypress open`

intro_first_test.title: Your First Test
intro_first_test.description: Write and run your first Cypress test
intro_first_test.content: Let's create a simple test to verify that a page loads correctly.

selectors_get.title: Using cy.get()
selectors_get.content: `cy.get()` is the most fundamental command in Cypress. It allows you to select DOM elements using CSS selectors.

concepts.title: Why cy.get()?
items: **Chainable**: Returns elements that can be further interacted with
**Retry-able**: Automatically retries until element is found or timeout

selectors_contains.title: Using cy.contains()
selectors_contains.description: Find elements by their text content
selectors_contains.content: `cy.contains()` allows you to select elements based on their text content, making tests more readable and maintainable.

selectors_find.title: Using .find()
selectors_find.content: The `.find()` command searches for descendant elements within a previously yielded element.

interaction_click.title: Clicking Elements
interaction_click.description: Learn how to click buttons and links
interaction_click.content: The `.click()` command simulates a user clicking on an element.

interaction_type.title: Typing Text
interaction_type.content: The `.type()` command simulates a user typing into an input field, with support for special characters and modifiers.

interaction_check.title: Checkboxes & Radio Buttons
interaction_check.description: Interact with checkboxes and radio buttons
interaction_check.content: Use `.check()` and `.uncheck()` to interact with checkboxes and radio buttons.

interaction_select.title: Select Dropdowns
interaction_select.content: The `.select()` command allows you to choose options from a `<select>` element.

assertions_should.title: Basic Assertions with .should()
assertions_should.content: The `.should()` command creates assertions about the state of elements.

concepts.title: Why .should()?
items: **Retry-able**: Automatically retries until assertion passes or timeout

assertions_expect.title: Using expect()
assertions_expect.content: `expect()` provides traditional assertion syntax for more complex validations.

assertions_visibility.title: Visibility Assertions
assertions_visibility.content: Learn how to verify if elements are visible, hidden, or exist in the DOM.

advanced_intercept.title: Network Interception
advanced_intercept.description: Mock and spy on network requests
advanced_intercept.content: `cy.intercept()` allows you to stub and modify network requests, making it easy to test different scenarios.

concepts.title: Why cy.intercept()?
items: **Control Network**: Stub API responses for consistent tests
**Test Edge Cases**: Simulate errors and edge cases
**Performance**: Tests run faster without waiting for real API calls

advanced_fixtures.title: Using Fixtures
advanced_fixtures.description: Load test data from external files
advanced_fixtures.content: Fixtures allow you to store test data in separate files, keeping your tests clean and maintainable.

advanced_custom_commands.title: Custom Commands
advanced_custom_commands.content: Custom commands let you create reusable functions that can be called throughout your tests.
